explanation:
1) process_short_params_str — This is the immediate caller that constructs and passes the param and next_param pointers into process_short_param. To decide if the controlling expressions (e.g. 'A' == param_chr) are invariant you must inspect how param is created/passed (literal constant, fixed buffer, or varying runtime data). process_short_params_str is the primary symbol that provides that context.  
2) process_params — This higher-level caller (caller of process_short_params_str) may set up the parameter source or call the short-params routine in a loop or with fixed arguments. Examining it is necessary to see whether param is always the same constant at every call site (making the comparisons effectively invariant) or whether it varies at runtime.  
Note: the individual process_param__* callees and PERF_RPL_PARAM_ERROR definition are not required to determine whether the controlling expressions in process_short_param are invariant, because they do not affect how param_chr is derived; only the call sites that supply param/next_param are relevant for this MISRA rule analysis.
